content: The Act may be cited as the "Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2003". References in the Act are considered to be made to the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Act includes provisions for the Javits Fellowship Program. The Graduate Opportunities in Higher Education Act of 2003 includes provisions for interruptions of study for exceptional circumstances like military service or illness, and allocation of fellowships from diverse geographic regions. The Act also ensures representation on the Board from various institutions. The Act ensures representation on the Board from institutions eligible for grants under title III or V. Amendments include changes to stipends and the Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program. The Act includes changes to stipends and the Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program, with adjustments to institutional allowances and authorization of appropriations for fiscal years. SEC. 3. GRADUATE ASSISTANCE IN AREAS OF NATIONAL NEED. The Secretary will establish a priority for grants to prepare individuals for the professoriate who will train teachers in math, science, special education, and limited English proficiency. Grants will provide program assistance and fellowships for post-baccalaureate teacher study. Grants will provide program assistance and fellowships for post-baccalaureate teacher study, including support for dissertation research in relevant fields. Collaboration is required for certain applications. In the context of grants for teacher preparation, collaboration with departments in all content areas is required to ensure effective training in teaching and content. Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program is established. Amendments are made to Section 721(c) to prepare students for law school, develop analytical skills, and promote completion. Thurgood Marshall Fellowships are awarded to eligible law school students who participated in summer institutes and are enrolled in accredited law schools. Amendments include eligibility criteria for Thurgood Marshall Fellowships for law school students who completed certified summer institute programs. Section 721(d)(1)(D) is amended to include services in analytical skills and study methods. Authorization of appropriations is extended until 2004. Subsection (e) of section 731 is repealed. SEC. 5. FUND FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF POSTSECONDARY EDUCATION. The amendment to Section 741(a) of the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education focuses on encouraging reform, innovation, and educational opportunities for all postsecondary students, especially non-traditional and those seeking academic credit for programs. It also emphasizes the establishment of institutions and programs utilizing communication technology, including distance education, and the implementation of institutional reforms. The amendment to Section 744 of the Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education focuses on international cooperation, partnerships, student exchange, and the establishment of academic programs supporting traditional American history education. The curr_chunk discusses support for planning, research, training, and technology transfers to enable institutions of higher education to work with organizations in addressing community issues like economic development, crime prevention, and healthcare. The curr_chunk discusses amending the authorization of appropriations for fiscal years to increase funding to $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and subsequent years. SEC. 6 repeals Part C of title VII (20 U.S.C. 1139 et seq.), while SEC. 7 focuses on demonstration projects for students with disabilities in higher education. The amendment to Section 762(a) expands services to all students with disabilities. Section 762(b)(2) is also amended to include effective transition practices for students with disabilities. The amendment to Section 762(a) expands services for students with disabilities, including innovative teaching methods for accessible distance education programs in higher education. The amendment expands services for students with disabilities in higher education, including replicating best practices from successful institutions. The amendment expands services for students with disabilities in higher education by updating funding allocation from fiscal year 1999 to fiscal year 2004 and extending it for the next 5 years. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on October 21, 2003.
